quoteFirst: Inoculating tubes of plain agar and 3% salt agar with this same material, we obtain in plain agar cultures organisms which are, typically, small, fairly slender rods, which do not stain characteristically at each end and are not oval. The smear obtained from the salt agar presents most remarkable involution forms—coccoid, root-shaped, sausage-shaped forms, ranging from
quoteLast: microns in length, more resembling cultures of moulds than bacteria. Another point is that on the inoculated plain agar we are in doubt at the end of twenty-four hours whether the dew-drop colonies are really bacterial colonies or only condensation particles.
title: The diagnostics and treatment of tropical diseases
author: Stitt, E. R. (Edward Rhodes), 1867-1948

quoteFirst: One of the largest sheets of fresh water in the West, Lake Pend d'Oreille will certainly yield to none in the beauty and variety of its scenery. Fifty-five miles in extreme length, and from
quoteLast: miles in width, it has an irregular shore line of probably 250 miles, richly diversified with rock and foliage, and surmounted by lofty ranges of hills. The railroad follows the north shore of the lake for about twenty-five miles, passing several little settlements, among which are Hope, Kootenai and Sand Point.
title:
Wonderland; or, Alaska and the inland passage
With a description of the country traversed by the Northern Pacific Railroad
author: Hyde, John, 1848-1929; Schwatka, Frederick, 1849-1892

quoteFirst: The remainder of the membership should comprise lords of parliament, as follows: (1) 100 elected from the peers possessing carefully stipulated qualifications, for a term of twelve years, on the principle of proportional representation, by the whole body of hereditary peers (including the Scotch and Irish), one-fourth of the number retiring triennially; (2) 120 members chosen by electoral colleges composed of members of the House of Commons divided for the purpose into local groups, each returning from
quoteLast: , under conditions of tenure similar to those prevailing in the first class; and (3) 100 appointed, from the peerage or outside, by the crown on nomination by the premier, with regard to the strength of parties in the House   (p. 111) of Commons, and under the before-mentioned conditions of tenure.
title: The Governments of Europe
author: Ogg, Frederic Austin, 1878-1951

quoteFirst: _Root._--A small membranous-coated corm. _Leaves._--Radical; linear; equaling the slender scape. _Scapes._--
quoteLast: inches high, bearing an umbel of small greenish-white flowers, subtended by several small lanceolate to linear bracts. _Pedicels._--Five to fifteen; two to twelve lines long.
title: The Wild Flowers of California: Their Names, Haunts, and Habits
author: Parsons, Mary Elizabeth, 1859-1947; Buck, Margaret Warriner, 1857-1929 [Illustrator]

quoteLast: inches long, soft, silky, much branched; branches rather short, and branchlets more or less curved and arranged in a comb-like manner. It grows on wharves, in muddy pools, and on eel-grass. (Plate IV.
